description: Assessment quiz for PowerShell basics knowledge

questions.question: What is the primary distinguishing feature of PowerShell compared to Bash?
options: PowerShell works with objects, while Bash works with text
questions.explanation: PowerShell is object-oriented, meaning it passes objects (with properties and methods) through the pipeline, while Bash and traditional shells work primarily with text strings.

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid PowerShell cmdlet naming convention?
questions.explanation: PowerShell cmdlets follow the Verb-Noun naming convention with PascalCase, like 'Get-Process'. This makes commands predictable and easy to discover.

questions.question: What cmdlet would you use to get a list of all running processes?
questions.explanation: Get-Process retrieves information about active processes. Get-Service is used for services, not processes.

questions.question: What does this command do? Get-ChildItem -Path 'C:\Users' -Filter '*.txt'
options: Lists all items in C:\Users and deletes .txt files
Lists all .txt files in the C:\Users directory
Lists all files and creates new .txt files
questions.explanation: Get-ChildItem lists directory contents, -Path specifies the directory, and -Filter '*.txt' limits results to .txt files.

questions.question: How would you navigate to your home directory in PowerShell?
questions.explanation: $HOME is a built-in variable that contains your home directory path. Set-Location (alias: cd) changes the current location.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the pipe operator (|) in PowerShell?
options: It passes the output of one cmdlet as input to another
questions.explanation: The pipe operator sends the output of the left command as input to the right command, enabling powerful command chaining and object manipulation.

questions.question: Which command would display the current working directory?
questions.explanation: Get-Location (alias: pwd or gl) displays the current working directory. It works cross-platform in PowerShell 7+.

questions.question: What does the following command do? Get-Process | Select-Object Name, CPU
options: Deletes processes and their CPU data
Gets all processes and displays only their Name and CPU properties
Gets processes and creates a CPU folder
Selects the Name process and filters by CPU
questions.explanation: Get-Process retrieves all processes, and Select-Object Name, CPU filters the output to show only those two properties.

questions.question: How would you create a new directory called 'Projects'?
questions.explanation: New-Item with -ItemType Directory creates a new folder. This works cross-platform in PowerShell 7+.

questions.question: What is the function of Get-Help in PowerShell?
options: It removes help files from your computer
It displays documentation and examples for cmdlets
questions.explanation: Get-Help provides comprehensive documentation for cmdlets, including syntax, parameters, and examples. Use Get-Help Get-Process -Examples to see practical use cases.

questions.question: What would this command output? Get-Process | Where-Object {$_.WorkingSet -gt 100MB} | Select-Object Name, @{Name='MemoryMB';Expression={$_.WorkingSet/1MB}}
options: Lists all processes with their names and CPU usage
Shows processes using more than 100MB of memory with a calculated MemoryMB column
Lists processes and their memory in bytes
questions.explanation: This filters processes using >100MB, then creates a custom property 'MemoryMB' by dividing WorkingSet (in bytes) by 1MB to show memory in megabytes.

questions.question: How would you read the contents of a file called 'data.txt'?
questions.explanation: Get-Content (alias: cat, type) reads and displays file contents. The -Path parameter specifies the file location.

questions.question: What's the difference between these two commands? 'Get-Service' vs 'Get-Service | Sort-Object Status'
options: They do exactly the same thing
The first lists services in default order; the second sorts them by Status
The first is faster than the second
questions.explanation: The pipe operator passes services to Sort-Object, which organizes them by Status. Without piping, Get-Service uses its default ordering.

questions.question: What does this command accomplish? Copy-Item -Path '.\source.txt' -Destination '.\backup\source.txt'
options: Moves source.txt to the backup folder
Copies source.txt to the backup folder
questions.explanation: Copy-Item duplicates the file from the source location to the destination. The original remains in place. Use Move-Item to move instead of copy.

questions.question: In PowerShell, what are the three main benefits of working with objects?
options: They're faster, simpler, and require less code
They have properties you can filter/sort, methods you can execute, and they maintain type information
Objects only work on Windows computers
They eliminate the need to learn PowerShell syntax
questions.explanation: Objects in PowerShell have properties (data about the object), methods (actions the object can perform), and type information, enabling powerful manipulation and automation.
